verses.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, whoever does not enter the sheepfold by the gate but climbs in another way is a thief and a robber.
verses.comment: Jesus uses the metaphor of the sheepfold to speak about true leadership of God's people. The Old Testament prophets also warn against false shepherds (Jer. 23:1; Ezek. 34:2).

verses.text: But the one who enters by the gate is the shepherd of the sheep.
verses.comment: The true shepherd comes properly, showing his rightful authority. Psalm 23 and Ezekiel 34 expect a divinely appointed shepherd, hinting at Jesus’ unique mission.

verses.text: To him the gatekeeper opens. The sheep hear his voice, and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.
verses.comment: God’s people recognize Jesus’ voice; this reflects intimate knowledge and personal leadership. The Old Testament imagery (Num. 27, Ezek. 34) shows God’s chosen leader leading the people out, reminiscent of Moses and David.

verses.text: When he has brought out all his own, he goes before them, and the sheep follow him because they know his voice.
verses.comment: The shepherd leads, not drives, his flock—a model for all spiritual leadership. The people of God are expected to recognize and follow the true shepherd’s authoritative teaching.

verses.text: But they will never follow a stranger; in fact, they will run away from him, because they do not recognize the voice of strangers.
verses.comment: True believers are able to discern between truth and error. Spiritual discernment is a recurring biblical theme (see Mark 13:22), emphasizing fidelity to the authentic shepherd.

verses.text: Jesus spoke this figure of speech to them, but they did not understand what he was telling them.
verses.comment: Jesus often used parables or figures of speech that required faith and openness to understand, foreshadowing the deeper revelation granted to those within his flock.

verses.text: So Jesus said to them again, 'Truly, truly, I say to you, I am the gate for the sheep.'
verses.comment: Jesus identifies himself as the exclusive means of access to the flock, echoing the 'I am' statements (John 14:6), which reveal his divinity and exclusive salvific role.

verses.text: All who came before me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not listen to them.
verses.comment: Jesus refers to false leaders who misled God’s people before him. The good sheep remain faithful, resisting false prophets and seeking authentic authority.

verses.text: I am the gate. If anyone enters through me, he will be saved; he will go in and out and find pasture.
verses.comment: Jesus again claims he is the only way to salvation and spiritual nourishment. This exclusivity further highlights his unique, divinely established role, contrasting other claimants.

verses.text: The thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy. I have come so that they may have life, and have it abundantly.
verses.comment: Jesus is the source of abundant life, reversing the work of the thief (the enemy). He offers a superabundant spiritual life that only he, as the divine shepherd, can provide.

verses.text: I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.
verses.comment: Here Jesus explicitly echoes Ezekiel’s prophecy of a shepherd from David’s line. This points to self-sacrificial leadership, fulfilled in Jesus’ atoning death—a high Christological claim.

verses.text: The hired hand, who is not the shepherd and does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and runs away; and the wolf attacks and scatters them.
verses.comment: Unlike the false shepherds, Jesus has a unique, personal ownership and fidelity to his flock—a mark of true spiritual guardianship.

verses.text: The hired hand runs away because he is a hired hand and cares nothing for the sheep.
verses.comment: Jesus distinguishes his own love and commitment from mere functionaries, consistent with prophetic warnings against negligent leaders.

verses.text: I am the good shepherd. I know my own and my own know me,
verses.comment: The mutual knowledge between Jesus and his followers is personal and profound, reflecting the intimacy of the divine-human relationship.

verses.text: just as the Father knows me and I know the Father; and I lay down my life for the sheep.
verses.comment: Jesus equates his relationship with the sheep to his relationship with the Father, revealing his divine sonship. Laying down his life is both an act of supreme love and the means of salvation.

verses.text: I have other sheep that are not of this fold. I must bring them also, and they will listen to my voice. There will be one flock, one shepherd.
verses.comment: Here, Jesus hints at the inclusion of the Gentiles and the unity of all believers under a single shepherd, emphasizing the importance of visible unity within the body of believers.

verses.text: For this reason the Father loves me—because I lay down my life so that I may take it up again.
verses.comment: Jesus’ obedience to the Father’s will includes his voluntary death and resurrection, which fundamentally show his divinity and mission.

verses.text: No one takes it from me, but I lay it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and I have authority to take it up again. This charge I have received from my Father.
verses.comment: Jesus asserts absolute authority over his life and death—proof of his divine sonship and unique mediatorship. This is not mere martyrdom, but the act of the divine shepherd.

verses.text: There was again a division among the Jews because of these words.
verses.comment: Jesus’ claims provoke division—his identity is divisive because of its high Christological and messianic implications.

verses.text: Many of them said, 'He has a demon and is out of his mind. Why listen to him?'
verses.comment: The accusation of demon possession is a common response to Jesus’ divine claims—his contemporaries struggle to accept the supernatural authority he displays.

verses.text: Others said, 'These are not the words of one possessed by a demon. Can a demon open the eyes of the blind?'
verses.comment: Others point to Jesus’ miracles (like giving sight to the blind) as evidence of divine endorsement and challenge the accusations against him.

verses.text: Then the Festival of Dedication took place at Jerusalem. It was winter,
verses.comment: The Festival of Dedication (Hanukkah) commemorated the rededication of the temple. Its mention underscores Jesus’ presence as the true temple and light during this season.

verses.text: and Jesus was walking in the temple in Solomon’s Colonnade.
verses.comment: Solomon’s Colonnade was a prominent place for teaching. Jesus’ presence in the temple signifies his role as the ultimate teacher and authority in Israel’s worship.

verses.text: So the Jews gathered around him and said, 'How long will you keep us in suspense? If you are the Messiah, tell us plainly.'
verses.comment: Many demand a clear statement about Jesus’ messianic identity. His previous teachings and miracles already reveal his divine nature, but some hearts remain hardened.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'I told you, and you do not believe. The works I do in my Father’s name bear witness about me,'
verses.comment: Jesus points to his miraculous works as proof of his identity. Faith is required not just in word, but in recognizing the deeds consistent with divine mission.

verses.text: but you do not believe, because you are not among my sheep.
verses.comment: Faith and belonging to Jesus are inseparable; those who are not of his sheep do not respond to his voice, showing the importance of remaining in the true fold.

verses.text: My sheep hear my voice, and I know them, and they follow me.
verses.comment: Spiritual intimacy is characterized by attentive hearing, knowing, and following—hallmarks of genuine discipleship within the community founded by Christ.

verses.text: I give them eternal life, and they will never perish, and no one will snatch them out of my hand.
verses.comment: Security is promised to those who belong to Christ. This is not only about perseverance, but about union with the Savior—a kind of assurance tied to remaining within the flock.

verses.text: My Father, who has given them to me, is greater than all, and no one can snatch them out of the Father’s hand.
verses.comment: The believer’s security lies in the power of God. Jesus states the close connection between himself and the Father—indicating the oneness of their will and mission.

verses.text: I and the Father are one.
verses.comment: A clear Christological statement—Jesus declares unity with the Father in essence, not just purpose. This foundational truth underpins the Church's belief in Jesus’ divinity.

verses.text: The Jews picked up stones again to stone him.
verses.comment: The crowd’s reaction shows they understood Jesus’ words as a claim to divinity, warranting the charge of blasphemy under Jewish law.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'I have shown you many good works from the Father; for which of them are you going to stone me?'
verses.comment: Jesus appeals to his works as evidence of his divine authority, pointing back to his miracles as outward signs affirming his identity.

verses.text: The Jews answered him, 'We are not stoning you for a good work but for blasphemy, because you, being a man, make yourself God.'
verses.comment: They clearly recognize his claim to deity. This verse powerfully confirms the high Christological teaching of Jesus’ divinity.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'Is it not written in your Law,
If he called them gods to whom the word of God came—and Scripture cannot be broken—
verses.comment: Jesus appeals to Psalm 82:6, highlighting both the authority of Scripture and the lesser uses of 'gods' for those exercising divine authority.

verses.text: do you say of him whom the Father sanctified and sent into the world, ‘You are blaspheming,’ because I said, ‘I am the Son of God’?
verses.comment: The title 'Son of God,' connected with divine consecration and mission, is a Messianic and uniquely divine claim, ultimately fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: If I am not doing the works of my Father, then do not believe me;
verses.comment: Jesus bases belief in him not only on claims but also on the works—miracles and signs—that validate his divine identity and mission.

verses.text: but if I do them, even though you do not believe me, believe the works, so that you may know and understand that the Father is in me and I in the Father.
verses.comment: Jesus insists that his unity with the Father is demonstrated by his miraculous works—another direct affirmation of his divinity.

verses.text: Again they tried to seize him, but he escaped from their hands.
verses.comment: Jesus’ hour had not yet come. His authority and mission are divinely protected until the appointed time.

verses.text: He went away again across the Jordan to the place where John had been baptizing at first, and there he stayed.
verses.comment: Jesus returns to the site of John’s ministry, which symbolically affirms the continuity between John’s baptism of repentance and Jesus’ ministry of salvation.

verses.text: Many came to him and said, 'John did no sign, but everything John said about this man was true.'
verses.comment: John’s witness is vindicated by Jesus’ works. The testimony of the prophets and apostles is confirmed by the presence and miraculous mission of Jesus.

verses.text: And many believed in him there.
verses.comment: The response of faith is a natural fruit of Jesus’ ministry. Those who truly hear the shepherd’s voice are gathered into one flock, demonstrating the importance of unity and faithfulness within the apostolic church.
